awd_titl_txt: PFI-TT: Evaluation of a Pilot Process to Convert Waste Oil and Grease from Waste Water Treatment Plants into Yellow Grease, Water and Solids for Reuse
awd_abstract_narration:
The commercial potential of this Partnerships for Innovation - Technology Translation (PFI-TT) project resides in the innovative, low cost and environmentally friendly approach developed to reuse fats, oils and greases (FOG) obtained from wastewater treatment plants (WWTPs). The broader impacts include benefits to the society, academic-industry collaboration, and entrepreneurship training to students.  FOGs are the number one cause of sewer pipe blockage worldwide and are usually landfilled as a nonhazardous waste. The cleanup is costly and the cost of landfill is also increasing.  An estimated 1 million tons of FOG from WWTPs is currently being landfilled at a cost of $50-100 million per year. Therefore, FOG reuse is critical to municipalities worldwide, which can also recover useful resources and lower carbon footprints of municipalities. This project will promote the adaptation of this environmentally friendly technology to reduce landfill waste disposal and sustainable energy generation. Landfill diversion is a need in most communities, and repurposed energy/materials will promote resource conservation.  This project will develop the knowledge and experience of the graduate student leader and four undergraduate students in the area of technology commercialization. This project will encourage participation of underrepresented groups. 

The proposed project will scale up the FOG separation process by demonstrating performance of a pilot system, which is a significantly stride to commercialization.  The resulting performance data will be then used to design and construct a commercial size system.  The objectives of this demonstration are to (1) establish the variability in composition of WWTP grease over time, (2) to produce sufficient separated yellow grease to test for usability in the production of biofuel, and (3) determine if byproduct solids and water can be reused as solid fuel/digester gas  and industrial water.   The intellectual merit of this technology is that the solvent-free extraction approach can overcome the challenges of FOG emulsion, impurities and high moisture content of the sewer grease, and can result in a low sulfur product that can be sold to downstream biofuel producers for biodiesel production. Other by-products derived from the process, such as water and solids, can also be marketable and offset the process cost. This process is low cost and environmentally friendly. This applied research can reduce start-up risk and facilitate subsequent commercialization.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this PFI-TT proposal is to address the technical hurdles of commercializing a solvent free process to reuse grease trap wastes (GTWs). Grease and oils leaking into sewer pipelines is the primary cause of sewer overflows in the US and around the world. Approximately 3 million tons of GTWs are produced in the US each year, much of which end up in waste water treatment plants (WWTPs) and are disposed of as waste. GTW upcycle is critical to municipalities worldwide, which can recover useful resources and also lower carbon footprints.

Intellectual Merit: In this project, longitudinal GTW characterization from two adjacent WWTPS were conducted seasonally for three years. In addition, two GTWs from out of states were also characterized. Using the solvent free extraction technology, three of the GTWs can be developed into a yellow grease product, which can be used as feedstocks of biodiesel. Without this technology, GTWs will result in a brown grease with lower market value while the resultant biodiesel can not meet sulfur requirements. Therefore, this project further affirmed that the solvent free extraction technology can be applicable to different types of GTWs.

A polit system of about 150 gallons were designed and built, and also tested at a WWTP. The resultant yellow grease can also be used as a biodiesel feedstock. The pilot system was creatively designed to be simple to operate and low cost, and resulted in a design patent. The project has resulted in one journal paper and three conference papers in the public domain that others can access and upcycle GTWs in their communities. This project has advanced the level of knowledge about GTW upcycle:  The lipid fraction can be extracted with the solvent free extraction technology in an environmentally friendly manner.

Broder impacts: GTW upcycle is critical to municipalities worldwide, which can recover useful resources and lower carbon footprints. GTW upcycle can help replenish the food and energy system of the municipality. Co-location with WWTPs can lower process cost due to the accessibility of GTWs and leveraging its treatment of unused fractions. The project has trained 1 graduate student and eight undergraduate students. Two student teams have used this idea for senior capstone design in Chemical Engineering. Our used cooking oil supplier is expanding its business to process GTWs and we put them in contact with one of the WWTPs we collaborated with.  

 


Last Modified: 08/18/2024
Modified by: Mingming Lu
